entry.title: Movable type and the typographers last words

p.small: Capital A in the font Ariella 36p.

div.p: Waldermar Lundberg, my father was born 1915. He was a printer and typographer and established a small workshop around 1947. The images here show some of the equipment he kept after his retirement 1975. He continued to work with printing and bookbinding until his death 2007.
Ariella was used for printing flyers and stuff.

All types were stored in rack cabinets like this. My father had a fairly complete set of Berling Antiqua, designed by Karl-Erik Forsberg (1914-1995) in the 1950s and produced by Berling type foundry here in Lund until 1980, when the company ended its more than 170 years in the graphical industry. The Berling Type Foundry was established in Copenhagen 1750 and continued its business there until 1783. It was then reestablished in Lund 1837.
Type pieces for large print was stored standing in rows.

After his retirement he worked here for about thirty years. Father had various printing presses including a large modern offset press. He kept these two old vintage tabletop printing presses until his death. He inherited one from a colleague and the other had been in his possesion since the 1940s.
This matrix is for printing a text on a book spine in one of the printing presses. They are the last words typeset by my father.
